abstract.p: Samples of Savonnières limestone subjected to repeated wetting–drying cycles were investigated by both neutron radiography and X-ray micro-tomography to collect information on saline uptake and salt precipitation. Capillary uptake of water, 1.4 molal sodium sulphate and 5.8 molal sodium chloride solution was visualized with neutron radiography. The liquid penetration coefficients and diffusivities were determined and are markedly lower for the salt solutions than for water, due to the higher surface tension and viscosity of salt solutions. Halite distributions were derived from neutron radiographs. Porosity analysis of X-ray tomographic datasets allowed quantifying thenardite distributions and porosity decrease due to salt crystallization.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Information on saline transport, salt crystal distributions and fracturing due to salt crystallization is essential for understanding the coupling between transport and mechanical processes related to salt weathering. This knowledge is required for the selection of appropriate materials and conservation methods for civil constructions and our cultural heritage. Additionally, such datasets are needed as a complement to numerical modelling research on crystallization in porous media as these data are indispensable for identification of phenomena to be included in models and for model validation.

Our aim is to collect threefold information on liquid transport, salt crystal distributions and fracturing processes on the same sample. Savonnières limestone is chosen as the porous material for our study, and samples are subjected to repeated wetting–drying cycles. Repeated uptake and drying of a salt solution should lead to the accumulation of an amount of salt inside the material sufficient for (1) the quantification of salt crystal distributions and (2) for inducing fracturing. Due to the repetitive character of the experiments, non-destructive techniques are needed. Transport of water and salt solutions has previously been studied by several techniques as described in Roels et al. (2004), such as nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) (Petkovic, 2005; Shahidzadeh-Bonn et al., 2010) and gamma-ray measurements (Rucker et al., 2000). As hydrogen highly attenuates neutron radiation, transmission-based neutron imaging should also be a well-suited technique to study liquid transport. The higher spatial resolution achievable with X-ray micro-tomography should allow assessing porosity changes and fracture formation due to salt crystallization. Therefore, we opted to combine neutron radiography and X-ray micro-tomography on our samples. Our study will thus additionally assess the usefulness of these two techniques for the study of salt crystallization in porous materials.

In this article, the wetting process by capillary uptake of salt solutions is discussed together with the salt crystal distributions that result after complete drying of the studied samples. The characterization of the drying process and the crystallization damage mechanisms will be the subject of a second publication, more details can be found in Derluyn (2012). The first part of this article describes the sample preparation, experimental set-up and the two imaging techniques. In the second part, the image processing and data analysis methods are discussed. The results are presented in the third part. The difference between water and saline uptake of sodium sulphate and sodium chloride solution is quantified. The salt crystal distributions are evaluated from neutron and X-ray micro-tomography results.

sec.title: Materials and sample preparation
sec.p: The stone studied is Savonnières limestone, a French layered oolitic limestone. This stone is widely available and is typically used for restoration projects (Dreesen and Dusar, 2004). Savonnières limestone is a quasi-pure calcitic stone without clay minerals. Hollow, dissolute cores of the oolites are characteristic for this limestone. The pore system was extensively studied by Roels (2000) and shows micro- (0.1–1 µm), meso- (10 µm) and macropores (100 µm range). The microstructure of the stone is depicted in Figure 1.

caption.p: Thin section of Savonnières limestone, showing different types of porosity: (1) intergranular microporosity, (2) intergranular macroporosity, (3) intragranular microporosity and (4) intragranular, moldic macroporosity.

sec.p: Capillary uptake was done with water, sodium sulphate or sodium chloride solution. Sodium sulphate and sodium chloride are two of the most damaging salts mentioned in the literature (Goudie and Viles, 1997). Sodium sulphate has two stable phases – mirabilite (Na2SO4·10H2O) and thenardite V (Na2SO4(V)) – and two metastable phases – heptahydrate (Na2SO4·7H2O) and thenardite III (Na2SO4(III)). Sodium chloride has one stable crystal phase above the freezing point: halite (NaCl). The different crystal phases are known to occur under different climatic conditions. By cooling a sodium sulphate solution, mirabilite or heptahydrate may form, while by drying, thenardite may also precipitate. Upon rewetting a stone containing thenardite, mirabilite may precipitate (Flatt, 2002). Crystallization of halite is mainly induced by drying.

Square prisms of Savonnières limestone of 10 × 10 mm2 base and 15.5–16 mm height were prepared. The bedding direction of the stone was parallel to the base. A hydrophobic treatment was applied on the top side (SILRES® BS 280, Wacker), and the samples were sealed on the lateral sides by a liquid and vapour-tight membrane (aluminium tape, which is quasi transparent to neutron radiation). The hydrophobic treatment was applied by painting the top side four times with a paint brush; the treatment penetrated the upper part of the stone over a depth between 2.7 and 4.7 mm. The aluminium tape ensured that no transport occurred through the lateral sides. The bottom 1–2 mm of the lateral sides was left open, but here one brush of hydrophobic treatment was applied. This was done to prevent preferential capillary uptake between the aluminium tape and the stone surface. From the bottom side, the samples were brought into contact with either water or a salt solution, after which capillary uptake occurred. At the end of the uptake, the bottom side was also sealed with tape and mastic (water and vapour tight). Thus, drying could only occur through the hydrophobically treated top side.

As the hydrophobic treatment prevented liquid transport, only vapour diffusion happened through the treated pores. The treatment was intended to prevent salt efflorescence at the surface and to induce in-pore crystallization. The confined crystallization would cause a build-up of interior stresses and a higher risk of fracturing the material. This process was intended as the study aimed at collecting combined data on transport and damage within a limited time frame. Additionally, the accumulated amount of salt could be controlled by weight monitoring without the problem of material loss, as efflorescence did not occur. The application of a hydrophobic treatment is also of practical interest as it is commonly applied on building materials for conservation purposes. However, such treatments often increase the risk for salt damage (Ioannou and Hoff, 2008).

The wetted samples are denoted with the prefix Wx, with x the sample number. Capillary uptake of samples wetted with deionized water (Wx_w), with 1.4 molal Na2SO4 solution (Wx_S) or with 5.8 molal NaCl solution (Wx_C) are visualized. The salt solutions were prepared with the same deionized water. The suffix of the sample names represents the number of wetting–drying cycles, for example, the visualization of the third wetting of sample W6 with 5.8 molal NaCl solution is referred to as W6_C3.

sec.title: Neutron radiography
sec.p: The capillary uptake experiments were performed at the NEUtron Transmission RAdiography (NEUTRA) beamline (Lehmann et al., 2001) and Imaging with COld Neutrons (ICON) beamline (Kaestner et al., 2011) of the Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen, Switzerland. These beamlines are fed by the Swiss Spallation Neutron Source (SINQ). Figure 2 shows the experimental set-up and a schematic overview of the neutron beamlines. The set-up contained a small sample holder; a custom-made elevator, supporting a container that was remotely controlled from outside the beamline; a neutron detector and high-density boronated polyethylene blocks to shield the elevator against neutron radiation in order to avoid building up radioactivity of the set-up components. The x- and y-axes in Figure 2 correspond to the detector plane, while the z-axis is aligned with the neutron beam direction, orthogonal to the detector plane. The detector consists of a scintillator–charge-coupled device (CCD) camera system, with a total field of view of 87 mm lateral size at NEUTRA and 27 mm at ICON. The scintillator was a plane slab of ZnS crystal, doped with 6Li as neutron absorbing agent (100 µm thick at NEUTRA and 50 µm at ICON). The scintillator converts the neutrons into visible light photons. The photons are then led via a mirror onto a cooled 16-bit CCD camera (1024 × 1024 pixels at NEUTRA, 2048 × 2048 pixels at ICON). A spatial resolution of 85 µm/pixel could be achieved at NEUTRA and of 13.5 µm/pixel at ICON. The exposure time per radiograph was 8 s at NEUTRA and 20 s at ICON. The sample–detector distance was 10 cm at NEUTRA and 5.5 cm at ICON.

caption.p: Schematic overview of the experimental set-up inside the NEUTRA beamline: (1) sample holder, (2) water/salt solution container, (3) remote-controlled elevator, (4) boron block for shielding, (5) detector, (6) collimator and (7) neutron source.

sec.p: A reference radiograph of the initial dry sample was taken right after the sample was placed on the sample holder and before it was in contact with water/salt solution. Then, the filled container was remotely moved up until the base of the sample was in contact with the free liquid surface, as confirmed by the visualization of a meniscus. From then on, radiographs were acquired at intervals of 24 s at NEUTRA and at 32 s at ICON, over a period of 60–180 min depending on the uptake rate of the different samples. The experiments were performed at 26°C and 48% RH at NEUTRA (climate inside the beamline in August 2010) and 22°C and 15% RH at ICON (December 2010). As a control reference, the total mass of intruded water/salt solution was determined by measuring the sample weight on a balance before and after the capillary uptake test. After the capillary uptake, the samples were sealed at the bottom with a tape and mastic paste on top of the tape and put in a closed box with desiccant. For the NEUTRA samples, the box was placed in the oven so that the samples dried at 40°C and approximately 5% RH. For the ICON samples, the box was put in the SINQ facility at ambient temperature, these samples dried at 20°C and 4% RH. We could not dry these samples in the oven as the experiments were performed during the last day of our allocated beamtime, and the samples could only be taken from the SINQ facility 1 week later as their radiation level after the experiment exceeded the safety level.

sec.title: Laboratory X-ray micro-tomography
sec.p: We acquired X-ray micro-tomographic datasets of all samples before wetting, thus at the ‘initial’ state, and after the last wetting–drying cycle, when the samples had completely dried out, the ‘weathered’ state. The samples were measured with an X-ray micro-tomography cone beam set-up present at EMPA Dübendorf, Switzerland. The set-up consists of a Viscom XT9160-TXD microfocus X-ray tube, a Micos UPR-160F Air rotation table and a Hamamatsu C7942 CA02 X-ray flat panel detector. A voltage of 80 kV was applied to accelerate the electrons, which impacted a tungsten micro-layer deposited on a diamond support. On the target, the electron beam had a power in the order of 1 W, and the focus size was ∼2 µm. The samples were mounted on the rotation table at 70 mm from the X-ray source, and the distance between the source and the detector was 500 mm. In total, 721 projection radiographs were acquired at angles uniformly distributed over 360°, where the last projection served as a check for the quality of the measurement, that is, the projections at 0° and 360° should be identical. Each radiographic image was binned by a factor of 2 × 2 in order to increase the signal-to-noise ratio. The projection radiographs counted 1120 × 1184 pixels. The total integration time for each projection radiograph was 4 s. In order to correct for the background noise of the CCD camera and inhomogeneities of the detector and beam, a dark-field and a flat-field image were acquired with a total integration time of 32 and 64 s, respectively. The projection radiographs were corrected for ‘hot’ pixels, beam hardening and ring artefacts (Boin and Haibel, 2006) before a standard, filtered back-projection algorithm was used for reconstructing the three-dimensional (3D) absorption tomographic datasets (Feldkamp et al., 1984). Considering the detector pixel size of 100 µm (2 × 2 binned) and a magnification of 7.14, a voxel size of 14 µm was obtained, which is larger than the focal spot size and ensured that the image was not blurred.

sec.title: Water and saline transport
sec.p: The neutron radiographs of the capillary uptake experiments were corrected for artefacts using the Quantitative Neutron Imaging (QNI) method developed by Hassanein et al. (Hassanein, 2006; Hassanein et al., 2005). The correction consists of standard procedures common to all radiation transmission-based imaging methods and of corrections specific for neutron imaging. The standard corrections comprise the acquisition of a dark-field (no neutron beam) and flat-field (no sample) image. The dark-field image compensates for the background noise of the CCD camera, that is, the presence of ‘warm’ and/or ‘hot’ pixels. The flat-field image is used to correct for the non-uniformity of the beam and inhomogeneities of the detector sensitivity. For each capillary uptake experiment, three dark-field and three flat-field images were taken before the start of the test. The neutron-specific corrections comprise corrections for neutron scattering and the polychromatic character of the beam. The interaction of neutrons with hydrogen, the main attenuating element in water or salt solution, mainly occurs as scattering. Therefore, the scattering correction is indispensable to obtain good quantitative results for liquid transport. The correction is based on Monte Carlo simulations of the main scattering component within the NEUTRA/ICON configuration. The main scattering component is considered to be the liquid, that is, water or salt solution. The application of the QNI method results in a corrected transmission value Tcorr, which allows for using the monochromatic exponential attenuation (Beer–Lambert) law

with t the time (s), µeff the effective attenuation coefficient (1/cm) and d (cm) the thickness of the main scattering component. The µeff values at a concentration of 1.4 and 5.8 molal were used for the Na2SO4 solution and NaCl solution, respectively. The radiographs of the dry and wet stones were evaluated for the thickness of liquid dldry and dlwet, respectively. These thicknesses are equivalent to the thickness that a layer of liquid would have to create the same transmission as the one measured. The moisture content w (kg/m3), retained by the stone, comprises the water and the salt ions in the liquid phase. For the specific material that we studied, the moisture transport can be considered as a mainly one-dimensional process (in the height direction). The moisture content at every height position was calculated for every acquisition time step. This provides the moisture content profiles in the sample with time. with l (mm) the position of the (sharp) moisture front and B (mm/s1/2) the penetration coefficient. As the moisture fronts are not strictly sharp (see Figure 3), l(t) was derived from the moisture profiles as the position at which the moisture content equals half of the maximal moisture content that can be reached at that position. In the upper part of the samples, lower maximal moisture contents and a slower penetration is found due to the hydrophobic treatment. The penetration coefficient for the pure Savonnières limestone is determined as the slope of the first part of the l(t)−t curve.

(2004, 2007) was applied. By plotting moisture profiles as a function of the Boltzmann variable, λ=y/t, instead of the position (in the height direction), y, the profiles are mapped on a single curve, defined as the lambda profile. sec.title: Salt crystal distributions and pore filling
sec.p: A neutron or X-ray radiograph of a dried sample after being wetted with salt solution contains combined information on the stone material and the precipitated salt. The amount of salt can be estimated by selecting the salt information from the attenuation image (negative logarithm of the transmission image T), thus
with µ the attenuation coefficient (1/cm) and d (cm) the thickness of the component. The amount of salt per unit of stone volume is then given by

We remark that we cannot use the same procedure here as for the determination of the moisture content (equation (2)), where the dry and the wet images are logarithmically subtracted. The dry salt containing image and the dry reference image of the pure stone are not acquired during the same experimental run, as the samples had dried outside of the neutron or X-ray beamline in order to reach the final dry salt containing state. When adding the dry salt–containing sample back in the beamline, it is impossible to put it at exactly the same position as the one of the dry reference samples (below µm precision would be needed). The sample might be rotated with respect to the reference position, by which pixel-wise subtraction cannot be performed correctly. Thus, we need to work with the single radiograph of the dry salt containing stone sample. For the neutron image correction, we can assume that the correction for the detector’s bias (dark-field image correction) and for the incident beam spatial inhomogeneity (flat-field image correction) is sufficient to allow using the Beer–Lambert law, as the scattering by the calcite stone and the non-hydrated salts should be limited. As a first approximation, an X-ray radiograph (although being acquired with a polychromatic beam) can also be approximated by the Beer–Lambert law after dark-field and flat-field image correction.

The salt will only be distinguishable when the contrast between the salt and the stone material is high enough, that is, when the attenuation coefficient and/or the salt thickness (the amount of salt) are high enough. An estimation of the attenuation coefficients for the different experimental set-ups is given in Table 1. It is remarkable that the attenuation coefficient of halite compared to limestone is more than five times higher for neutron radiation. The attenuation coefficient of thenardite for neutron radiation is similar to the one of limestone. For X-ray radiation, the attenuation coefficients of limestone and both salts are in the same range. With the salt crystal amounts collected in our samples, we found that the analysis method based on equation (6) only works for determining halite distributions from neutron radiographs. In the other cases, the change in transmission values due to the presence of salt crystals is less than the fluctuations of the transmission value for the stone material over the sample area. Thus, thenardite distributions cannot be quantified from a single neutron radiograph. Neither halite nor thenardite distributions can be quantified from a single X-ray radiograph.

sec.p: A second method to derive salt crystal distributions is to compare the initial and final states for microstructural changes. Therefore, the X-ray tomographic datasets of the initial and the weathered samples were aligned by using an image registration algorithm developed by Latham et al. (2008). The registration was performed to ensure that the same slices of the initial and the weathered datasets were compared when doing quantitative analysis. For fractured samples, the fractured part could not be registered to its initial state, as the corresponding slices from the weathered tomographic dataset are shifted with respect to the initial dataset due to the fracture displacements. Hence, only unfractured samples are further analysed to derive salt crystal distributions. In fractured parts, the microstructural change is a coupled effect of the salt precipitation (porosity decrease) and of the crack formation (porosity increase) and cannot be used to assess salt precipitation solely.

The datasets were compared in terms of their porosity change using the software Morpho+(Brabant et al., 2011). They were first filtered to improve the signal-to-noise ratio, using the bilateral filter. Then, thresholding was applied by selecting the grey-scale interval of the pore space on the histogram of the image stack. The same interval range was used for the initial and weathered datasets. This created binary datasets representing the pore space. From this, the porosity distribution over the height of the sample was calculated, within the limits of the obtained effective spatial resolution (14 µm). This means that only the macroporosity of the hollow oolites and the intergranular pores could be accounted for. By subtracting the weathered porosity distribution from the initial one and assuming that all changes of porosity are due to the presence of salt crystals, salt crystal distributions were obtained.

sec.title: Water and saline transport
sec.p: Twelve samples were processed with the QNI method. A general overview is given in Table 2. The final mass of water or salt solution taken up, as determined from the image analysis and from weighing on the balance, is given. A difference of less than 2% is found (except for sample W6 where the difference is higher due to fluctuations in the neutron results). As the samples had high moisture contents, it is not surprising that the QNI correction procedure was needed to achieve a good quantification of the moisture mass. Without it, differences up to 15% were observed.

sec.p: Five samples (W1–W5) were wetted with water. The two-dimensional (2D) moisture distribution of sample W2 as resulting from the image analysis of the transmission images is given for three time steps in Figure 3. Based on the grey value range of the dry and wet neutron images (a method used, for example, in Roels and Carmeliet, 2006), the moisture content resolution amounts to 0.04 kg/m3. We remark that in the bottom corners, the moisture content is slightly lower due to the application of one brush of hydrophobic treatment to prevent preferential uptake between aluminium foil and stone surface, as explained in the ‘Materials and sample preparation’ section. The moisture profiles were calculated for the central part of the samples (average over one-third of the width), indicated as the area between the two white lines in Figure 3. From the final moisture profile, we can conclude that the maximal moisture content is about 140 kg/m3 for sample W2 in the first 13 mm of the sample. There are some fluctuations, however, due to the heterogeneous character of the stone. At higher positions, the maximal moisture content gradually decreases due to the hydrophobic treatment that has distributed from the top. Liquid flow to the outer top of the sample is prevented by the hydrophobic treatment.

The moisture profiles at the end of the capillary uptake test are given in Figure 4 for the five samples. The penetration depth of the hydrophobic treatment can be estimated from these profiles as the position at which the maximal moisture content starts to show a constant decrease. For the samples of the NEUTRA test series, a penetration depth between 2.7 and 3.7 mm is found, indicated by the arrow. For the samples of the ICON test series, prepared at a later time from a different plate of Savonnières limestone, the penetration depth lies between 3.7 and 4.7 mm.

caption.p: Moisture profiles of the five samples wetted with water at the end of the capillary uptake experiments. The arrows indicate the depth into which the hydrophobic treatment might have penetrated. For samples W1 and W2, a constant decrease in moisture content is observed at 13 mm, indicating a hydrophobic zone of ±2.7 mm. For samples W3 and W4, the hydrophobic zone amounts to ±3.7 mm and for sample W5, ±4.7 mm.

sec.p: From the moisture profiles, moisture front positions, penetration coefficients, lambda profiles and diffusivities were calculated following equations (3) and (4). The moisture fronts for the water-wetted samples are given in Figure 5(a). The five samples show a similar penetration coefficient, B. The penetration coefficient values are determined from the data points of the first 15 min of the test, in order to consider only the behaviour of the pure Savonnières limestone without the influence of the hydrophobic treatment. The values are given in Table 2. The values correspond to values reported by Roels (2000), he measured an average penetration coefficient of 0.34 mm/s1/2 on Savonnières limestone.

caption.p: Moisture fronts as a function of square root of time for samples wetted with (a) water, (b) 1.4 molal Na2SO4 solution and (c) 5.8 molal NaCl solution. The penetration coefficient B is determined by the curve’s slope.

sec.p: After complete drying, samples W2 and W5 were wetted with 1.4 molal sodium sulphate solution and sample W3 with 5.8 molal sodium chloride solution. In this way, a clear comparison could be made between water and salt solution imbibition, as the measurements were done on the same sample. The moisture content resolution for both salt solutions is 0.04 kg/m3. The resulting moisture fronts are given in Figure 5(b) and (c), and the penetration coefficients are given in Table 2. It is found that the water uptake is faster than the salt solution uptake and that the ratio Bsalt_sol/Bwater is 0.73 and 0.74 for samples W2 and W5 (uptake of sodium sulphate solution), respectively, and 0.80 for sample W3 (uptake of sodium chloride solution). According to Washburn (1921), the part of the penetration coefficient depending on the liquid type is proportional to σ/η, with σ the surface tension (mN/m) and η the viscosity (mPa·s). This means that Bsalt_sol/Bwater equals (σsalt_sol·ηwater)/(ηsalt_sol·σwater). At 25°C, the viscosity of water, 1.4 molal sodium sulphate solution and 5.8 molal sodium chloride solution is 0.89, 1.68 (Glass and Madgin, 1934) and 1.69 mPa·s (Kestin et al., 1981), respectively. The surface tension amounts, respectively, to 72, 75 (Matubayasi, 2012, personal communication) and 80 mN/m (Ali et al., 2006). For sodium sulphate salt solutions, the ratio Bsalt_sol/Bwater is 0.74 and for sodium chloride salt solution, 0.77. These ratios are close to the ones obtained from the neutron measurements. Thus, the penetration coefficient B scales as σ/η.

This result suggests that the diffusivity will scale as σ/η (Reinhardt, 1997). Lambda profiles were determined; an example is given for sample W5 in Figure 6(a). The lambda profile is obtained from the moisture profiles in the first 9 mm of the sample, below the hydrophobic zone. A shift of the lambda profile for salt solution uptake is observed with respect to water uptake. An analytical fit on the data was made, and from this fit, the liquid diffusivity was calculated by applying equation (4). The result for sample W5 is shown in Figure 6(b). When scaling the water diffusivity on the salt solution diffusivity by a factor 0.58 (=(σsalt_sol/ηsalt_sol)/(σwater/ηwater)), a good agreement is found. Thus, diffusivity scales indeed as σ/η. The fulfilment of these scaling laws indicates that we can assume that Savonnières limestone is microscopically unchanged by contact with water or salt solution (Reinhardt, 1997); hence, we can assume that no chemical reaction processes occur between the stone matrix and the fluid.

caption.p: (a) Lambda profiles of sample W5 for water uptake (_w) and 1.4 molal Na2SO4 solution uptake (_S) (dots: experimental data; lines: analytical fit). (b) The liquid diffusivity determined from the lambda profiles: the salt solution diffusivity can be predicted well by scaling the water diffusivity with the ratio (σsalt_sol/ηsalt_sol)/(σwater/ηwater).

sec.p: Four samples underwent wetting–drying cycles with a 5.8 molal sodium chloride solution before being visualized at the neutron beamlines. For these samples, only the third (W6, W7) or fourth (W8, W9) capillary uptake was visualized. The samples show an uptake similar as what is seen in sample W3 (Figure 5(c)), illustrating the repeatability of the test when working with alike samples. However, the penetration coefficient, given in Table 2, is slightly lower. This is most probably due to some pore blocking by halite crystals at the bottom of the sample. Although the samples were carefully sealed at the bottom during the drying phase (with a tape and a mastic paste above the tape), some salt powder was observed on the tape after removal.

sec.title: Salt crystal distributions and pore filling
sec.p: The zone of salt precipitation for sodium chloride–wetted samples can be clearly seen in the neutron radiograph of the dry state, as shown for sample W6 in Figure 7(a). As chlorine attenuates the neutron beam more than the calcite stone, the location of the NaCl crystals shows up darker than the stone material. Thus, brighter grey tones mean a lower halite content, while darker tones indicate a larger content. Based on the grey value range of the stone with and without salt, the halite content resolution is estimated to be in the order of 0.2 kg/m3. From the transmission image, a 2D distribution of the volumetric salt crystal content was calculated (Figure 7(b)), using equation (6). We remark that there can be some artefacts in the calculated 2D distribution, especially at the borders of the sample. These artefacts consist in apparent halite presence at the sample’s boundaries and are due to the sealing with aluminium foil and the incident neutron beam diffraction at the sample’s boundaries. Therefore, the average value at every height was calculated for the central part of the samples (average over one-third of the width, bordered by the black lines in Figure 7(b)), resulting in the salt crystal distribution. The obtained halite distributions for samples W6–W9 are depicted in Figure 7(c). We observe that halite mainly precipitates in the lower part of the hydrophobic zone and just below this zone. For samples W8 and W9, we remark that some halite also precipitated at the bottom side of the sample.

sec.p: The total salt weight in the whole sample was found by summing up all pixel values in the central area and multiplying by 3. The comparison between the halite weights determined from the image analysis and measured by balance is given in Table 3. The image analysis leads to underestimations of 2%–5% for samples visualized at NEUTRA and overestimations of about 10% for samples probed at ICON. Overall, the halite weights obtained by neutron radiography can be considered as good estimates.

sec.p: All samples in which halite precipitated (W3 and W6–W9) were fractured in their final state. For these samples, no salt distributions could be derived by comparison between the X-ray tomographic datasets. Samples W2, W5 and two extra samples W10 and W11, in which sodium sulphate precipitated, were not damaged. For these samples, the porosity of the initial and of the final, that is, weathered, state was compared by calculating the porosity of stacks of 10 slices over the height of the sample. An example of the initial and weathered porosity profiles is given for sample W10 in Figure 8(b). The difference between both results gives the porosity decrease as shown in Figure 9(a), indicating the presence of thenardite in the hydrophobic zone and just below, similar to halite. Sample W5 is not included in the graph, as no significant porosity change could be resolved. This sample had only undergone one wetting–drying cycle. An overview of the total porosity values for the whole sample volume is given in Table 4.

sec.p: As a first estimation, differences in porosity only start to be significant upon a difference above 0.5%, corresponding to a thenardite crystal content of about 15 kg/m3. Thus, thenardite crystals can only be resolved when the amount of crystals in pores larger than 14 µm, the spatial resolution of the tomographic datasets, exceeds a value of 15 kg/m3. Additionally, crystals can be present in pores smaller than 14 µm. These crystals cannot be resolved with the analysis method based on the porosity change, as these smaller pores/crystals cannot be detected as unfilled/filled pore space.

From the porosity change in the zone of 4–5 mm where thenardite formed, the corresponding weight can be calculated. A significant underestimation of 60%–75% is found compared to the balance measured weight (see Table 5). This means that the sodium sulphate crystals precipitated also in pores smaller than 14 µm, the resolution of the tomographic datasets acquired in the laboratory set-up. Therefore, the porosity decrease profiles were multiplied by the ratio of the balance mass to the mass determined from the X-ray datasets in order to obtain the salt content distribution as given in Figure 9(b). This assumes that the salt crystals were evenly distributed over the pore space and thus that crystals in pores smaller than 14 µm must have formed in the same region as where the crystals in the larger pores are found, that is, at the top of the stone sample.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We have shown that we can obtain a comprehensive dataset on water/saline uptake and salt distributions in limestone samples subjected to repeated wetting–drying cycles, which were treated hydrophobically on their upper part. This was done by combining two non-destructive imaging techniques: neutron radiography and X-ray micro-tomography. We could visualize and quantify the uptake process of water and salt solutions and the deposition of salts. A good quantification of water and saline uptake could be obtained, showing a decrease of the penetration coefficient and of the diffusivity for saline solutions compared to water. The penetration coefficient is proportional to the square root of the surface tension to viscosity ratio (σ/η), and the diffusivity is proportional to the surface tension to viscosity ratio (σ/η). The distribution of halite crystals was obtained from neutron radiographs of dry samples, and a good quantification of the salt amount could be obtained. By comparing the porosity results of X-ray tomographic datasets of a sample in its initial and salt-filled state, the distribution of thenardite crystals was determined (when cracking had not yet occurred). The crystal distribution profiles of halite as well as thenardite show that the salts precipitate in the upper region of the samples, partly in the hydrophobic zone and partly just below this zone. The location of salt precipitation is mainly related to the drying process in the samples (Derluyn, 2012).
